intro: Sticherus hirtus var. candidus, commonly known as the white-haired sticherus, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes caraway and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges or along stream banks. Its hairy stems and leaves give it a distinctive appearance, making it a notable species in botanical gardens and natural habitats.
